did.unittitle: Western Americana card photograph file.

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.physdesc: circa 1000 photographic prints : b & w ; on mounts 22 cm. x 30 cm. or smaller.
did.abstract: This collection consists of card photographs of various sizes and formats, as well as unmounted photographic prints, circa 1851-1965. The collection documents a broad range of commercial photography between 1860 and 1910, mainly created by regional operators and traveling photographers. The collection also includes examples by renowned photographers, such as Frank Jay Haynes, William Henry Jackson, Alexander Martin, Charles Roscoe Savage, Isaiah West Taber, and Carleton E. Watkins.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Acquired from various sources

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.
This collection has no permanent box or folder designations for items within it, so patrons should note the photographer and image description when requesting materials

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Western Americana Card Photograph File is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, may belong to the photographers or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Western Americana Card Photograph File. Yale Collection of Western Americana, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

bioghist.head: History of the Collection
bioghist.p: This collection derives from an illustration file maintained by the staff of the Yale Collection of Western Americana since 1952. The collection has served as a means for bringing together photographic materials acquired singularly and in small groups. Occasionally, a critical mass of photographs by a particular photographer or studio accrue within the collection and becomes the basis for an artificially created collection documenting that individual. This collection continues to embody this dynamic function and groups of photographic material will continue to become the basis of smaller individual collections.

During the late twentieth century, archivists preliminarily arranged and briefly described the collection in a print finding aid. In 2008, the print finding aid served as the basis for a thorough examination and detailed description of the collection.
Prior to 2008, library staff did not routinely document provenance information.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection consists of card photographs of various sizes and formats, as well as unmounted photographic prints. The collection documents a broad range of commercial photography between 1860 and 1910, mainly created by regional operators and traveling photographers. The collection also includes examples by renowned photographers, such as Frank Jay Haynes, William Henry Jackson, Alexander Martin, Charles Roscoe Savage, Isaiah West Taber, and Carleton E. Watkins.

The imagery provides diverse visual documentation of the natural and built environment, as well as portraits of the inhabitants of the American West during the late nineteenth and early twentieth centuries. Specific images include informal and studio portraits of American Indians and settlers, as well as views of cities and towns, mining and logging operations, railroads, military installations, agricultural activities, American Indian reservations, and natural scenery in and about the American West.

Image descriptions of photographic prints derive from inscriptions on the verso and recto of the item and from image analysis by the archivist. Descriptions of items in this finding aid include the dimensions of each photographic print in centimeters and the dimensions of its mount (when present) in centimeters. Descriptions usually include information about the working locations of photographer, and occasionally physical characteristics of items, such as image numbers applied by the photographer or inscriptions by a previous owner, as well as contextual information about the image.
Each folder contains a single photographic print, except when noted in the item description.

Most of the items in this collection are photographic prints mounted on cardboard, known as card photographs. During the nineteenth century, card photographs were a popular way to present photographic prints, especially carte-de-visite and cabinet photographs. The mounts for card photographs vary in format and dimensions, and the mounted photographic prints vary in technical processes. The photographic prints are usually albumen prints, but also include collodion prints, cyanotypes, gelatin silver prints, platinum prints, and salted paper prints.

Introduced in the United States in 1860, carte-de-visite photographs gain their name from French calling cards. The photographic prints, which usually measure 8.89 x 6.35 cm (2.125 Ã— 3.5 in.), were mounted on cardboard 10 x 6 cm (2.5 X 4.5 in.). Carte-de-visite photographs remained a popular form in the United States into early 1870s, when they were largely replaced by cabinet photographs.

Cabinet photographs are larger than carte-de-visite photographs, usually 9.5 x 13.8 cm (3.5 x 5.5 in.), mounted on cardboard 10.5 x 16.4 cm (4.5 by 6.25 in.). Cabinet cards remained popular during the last two decades of the nineteenth century, as did other sized formats, including boudoir midget mounts, 5.1 x 8.6 cm (2 x 3.375 in.); victoria cards, 8.3 x 12.7 cm (3.25 x 5 in.); promenade photographs, 10.2 x 17.8 cm (4 x 7 in.); boudoir photographs, 13.3 x 21.6 cm (5.25 x 8.5 in.); imperial photographs, 17.5 x 25.1 cm (6.875 x 9.875 in.); and panel photographs, 29.5 x 10.2 cm (8.25 x 4 in.).

Card photograph mounts often have printed or embossed decorations conveying advertisements about the photographer, the studio, and location, as well as awards, areas of expertise, or prominent patrons. Photographers and other individuals, such as the subjects in the image or the collector of it, often wrote descriptive inscriptions about the photograph on the verso or recto of the cardboard mount.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into three series. Series I. Identified Photographers. Series II. Unidentified Photographers. Series III. Oversize.
Given the dynamic nature of this collection, items will move in and out of the collection. The collection has no permanent box or folder designations for items in each series.

did.unittitle: Identified Photographers

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of photographic prints and their accompanying mounts that have dimensions less than 22 x 29 cm (8.7 x 11.4 in.) in size and created by identified photographers. Materials with larger dimensions are located in Series III. Oversize.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Photographs in this series are arranged in alphabetical order by surname of the photographer or the corporate name of a studio that created them and then chronologically therein.

View of Central City, Colorado
did.physdesc: 14.0 x 9.7 cm on mount 16.6 x 10.8 cm

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Typescript on verso: "Central City is the oldest mining town in Colorado. It is situated in the heart of the mining region, is the country seat of Gilpin County, has a population of about five thousand people, and has an elevation of from 8,000 to 8,900 feet above the level of the sea. It is midway between Black Hawk and Nevada, forming with them a continuous town that is connected by rail with the K. P. and U. P. Railways."

did.unittitle: View of a bridge at Boulder, Colorado
did.physdesc: 13.5 x 9.5 cm on mount 16.6 x 10.7 cm

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Typescript on verso: "From Boulder City, looking southwest. Boulder City, from which this view is taken, is situated near the base of the mountains at an elevation of 5,536 feet above the sea, in the heart of one of the best agricultural regions of Colorado, watered by the beautiful crystal waters of the Boulder, whose banks are fringed with luxuriant foliage. It has excellent public school buildings, churches, etc., and two railroads connecting it with the east - the Boulder Valley and Colorado Central. Cliffs of sandstone are seen in the back-ground."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Typescript list of available titles printed on verso, in addition to: "Address, Bailey, Dix, & Mead, Fort Randall, D. T." and "This noted Chief, With his band of Uncapapa Sioux Indians, now prisoners of war at Fort Randall, D. T., is 43 years of age; Weight 200 pounds; Height, 5 ft., 9 in. Has had over 100 engagements with their natural enemies, the Crows, of which he proudly boasts, but is too shrewd to acknowledge to having killed any whites. He has had 9 wives. The two now living with him appear with descriptions in Nos. 5, 11, and 20. Has had one child by each of his first 6 wives."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Title on verso of cabinet card with photographer's information: "Address, Bailey, Dix & Mead, Fort Randall, D. T.," list of other subjects and description: "A Nes (sic) Perce Indian, who escaped from his band, while surrounded in the bad lands of Nebraska, by Gen'l Miles, in 1878. He then joined Sitting Bull's band of Uncapapa Sioux Indians in the British possessions and has followed their fortunes ever since. He lost his feet above the ankles, also his right hand by being frozen, having been caught in one of the severe snow storms, 21 years ago."

did.unittitle: Dellenbaugh, Frederick Samuel (1853-1935), collector

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Frederick Samuel Dellenbaugh was an American explorer. From 1871 to 1873, he served as an artist and assistant topographer with the second expedition led by John Wesley Powell down the Colorado River. In 1899, he joined an expedition to Alaska and Siberia financed by Edward Henry Harriman. He served as librarian of the American Geographical Society (1909-1911) and a fellow of the American Ethnological Society.

did.unittitle: Studio portrait of Almon Harris Thompson (1839-1906)
did.physdesc: 9.6 x 6.3 cm, unmounted tintype

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Thompson was the chief assistant of John Wesley Powell during expeditions of the Colorado River and the surrounding plateau country from1870 to 1878, a geographer with the United States Geological Survey (1882-1906), and uncle of Frederick Samuel Dellenbaugh

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Group portrait of a boy, four women, and nine men on the top of Mount Hood, Oregon, after an ascent from August 15-23, 1892. The portrait includes Frederick A. Walpole, a lithographer in Portland, Oregon.
A brief account of the ascent appears in Earl Morse Wilbur, "An Ascent of Mount Hood," Outing , Volume 24 (August 1894): 348-353

did.unittitle: Unidentified Photographers

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of photographic prints and their accompanying mounts that have dimensions less than 22 x 29 cm (8.7 x 11.4 in.) in size and created by unidentified photographers. Materials with larger dimensions are located in Series III. Oversize.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Photographs in this series are organized into two subseries: Identified Locations and Portraits.

did.unittitle: Identified Locations

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This subseries is organized according to image content, initially in alphabetical order by geographical locations in the United States, first by states and therein by localities, then by locations in Canada and other countries, then by images with unidentified locations arranged according the subject in the image and chronologically therein.

did.unittitle: South Dakota
Cheyenne River
View of a cattle herd during a roundup by cowboys on horseback near the Cheyenne River and forty-three miles from Custer, South Dakota, on the road to Cheyenne, Wyoming
did.physdesc: 9.2 x 17.2 cm on mount 10.0 x 17.2 cm

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Manuscript on verso: "This is one outfit that I am with on the Roundup. They are camped about one mile from the Roundup. We make one roundup a day more 10 to 15 miles to make another. There was about 200 men on this roundup and each man has from 5 to 8 head of horses to ride. I expect you will figure up the number of horses [and] say you would like to count them but I will leave you to draw your own conclusions as to the facts. I am on a white face horse right opposite of the wagon I will make a cross right by my horse. L.S.G. - P.S. You can see the Cheyenne River in the distance it is a beautiful stream and a splendid range 43 miles from Custer on the road to Cheyenne City. In this picture we have drove the horses into camp and are about to change to set a fresh horse to ride. We change 2 to 3 times a day & ride from 50 to 75 miles a day, not right strait [sic] ahead but in what we call a circle that is getting all the cattle together each day and not get any cattle one day that we had the day before. L.S.G."

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This component is organized by the surname of individual subjects, followed by unidentified individuals, then by groups of individuals organized by the surname of the first identified individual on the far left of the frame followed by groups of unidentified individuals.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of photographic prints and their accompanying mounts that have dimensions greated than 22 x 29 cm (8.7 x 11.4 in.) in size and created by identified and unidentified photographers. Materials with smaller dimensions are located in Series I and Series II.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series is identified into two subseries: Identified Photographers and Unidentified Photographers.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Photographs in this subseries series are organized in alphabetical order by surname of the photographer or the corporate name of a studio and then chronologically and by image subject.
